title: Interpreting a signaling pathway Set member 1

content.description:
Figure 1. Pathway activated by insulin binding to the insulin receptor

Figure 2: Blood insulin levels in normal mice and <math alttext="E s p" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> mutant mice after exposure to glucose

Hormones are chemical signals that are released by cells in one part of the body that travel through the bloodstream to signal cells in another part of the body. Insulin is a hormone that is released by the pancreas that induces the uptake of glucose molecules from the bloodstream into cells. In this way, insulin lowers the overall blood glucose levels of the body. Osteoblasts and osteoclasts are two types of bone cells that play a role in regulating blood glucose levels (FigureÂ 1).

Binding of insulin to the insulin receptor on osteoblasts activates a signaling pathway that results in osteoblasts releasing a molecule, <math alttext="O P G" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OPG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, that binds to neighboring osteoclasts. In response, the osteoclasts release protons (<math alttext="H with a plus one charge" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>) and create an area of lower <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> outside the cell. This low <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activates osteocalcin, a protein secreted in an inactive form by osteoblasts.

The <math alttext="E s p" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene encodes a protein that alters the structure of the insulin receptor on osteoblasts and interferes with the binding of insulin to the receptor. A researcher created a group of osteoblasts with an <math alttext="E s p" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> mutation that prevented the production of a functional <math alttext="E s p" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> product (mutant). The researcher then exposed the mutant strain and a normal strain that expresses <math alttext="E s p" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to glucose and compared the levels of insulin in the blood near the osteoblasts (Figure 2).
content.question: Based on the information provided, which of the following best justifies the claim that osteocalcin is a hormone?

choices.label: The phosphorylation of the insulin receptor causes a response in osteoblast bone cells.
The osteoblasts in the bone secrete osteocalcin, which causes cells in the pancreas to change their activity.

The change in expression of <math alttext="E s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> changes the insulin receptor activity of the osteoblast.
The activation of the osteocalcin by a bone cell is <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> dependent.

content.answer: The osteoblasts in the bone secrete osteocalcin, which causes cells in the pancreas to change their activity.
